children.title: plants
children.comment: Plants are an important aspect of God's creation, and a major source of food and materials. Scripture refers to many plants, with their various uses.

cschildren.title: Plants as a source of food
Growth of plants dependent upon soil, sun and irrigation

children.title: food
children.comment: Scripture contains references to varied foodstuffs, which comprised the diet of the people of the Near East in biblical times.

cschildren.title: God made provision for food in creation

children.title: Flour the main ingredient in bread
Flour figured largely in the staple diet
Fine flour more refined and more expensive than the common variety
The promised land described as flowing with milk and honey
Prohibition against burning honey on the altar

cschildren.title: Believers should not eat food offered to idols

children.title: agriculture
children.comment: The science of cultivation. The task, given to humanity, of cultivating the land is a reflection of God's own care for his creation.

cschildren.title: Growth is according to the sovereign will of God

children.title: He provides for the growth of the crops
OT laws for agriculture showed how to co-operate with God
Harvest festivals were for thanking God for his provision

cschildren.title: Cultivation was affected by the fall
Agricultural images of God's action among his people
Balm was a herb valued for its healing properties
Balm was exported from Israel to other nations

children.title: banquets
children.comment: Grand, celebratory meals consisting usually of rich food and flowing wine. Banquets usually accompanied weddings, religious festivals and other celebrations. Prophecies of the Messianic age refer to a banquet to which the righteous will be invited.

children.title: They were usually held in a hall
Honoured guests were given special places

seealsos.comment: a feast celebrates Jacob's wedding
Samson gives a wedding feast
Xerxes celebrates Esther's choice as queen with a banquet
the marriage supper of the Lamb

secondaryrefs.comment: Abraham celebrates Isaac's weaning.
The father celebrates the prodigal son's return.
Isaac holds a feast for Abimelech
Joseph feasts with his brothers
David holds a feast for Abner
Solomon gives a feast for all his court.
Queen Vashti holds a banquet for the women of the palace.
Belshazzar has a banquet for 1,000 nobles
Levi holds a banquet for Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ is the guest of a leading Pharisee.

cschildren.title: An invitation to a banquet seen as a sign of God's grace

seealsos.comment: The king of Israel prepares a banquet for captured Aramean troops

cschildren.title: Binding corn as a feature of agricultural life

seealsos.comment: the law of the gleaner

children.title: branch
children.comment: The limb of a tree. The term is used literally, symbolically and metaphorically in Scripture. Branches are personified at times and the Messiah is referred to as the Branch.

cschildren.title: Branches cut down for Jesus Christ's triumphal entry into Jerusalem
The branches of the lampstand in the tabernacle

children.title: bread
children.comment: The basic component of the staple diet in biblical times. Consecrated bread was continually laid out in the Holy Place of the tabernacle and temple. Jesus Christ called himself the bread of life.

cschildren.title: Bread the basic component of the diet

seealsos.comment: Abraham entertains the three angels
Gideon asks for bread for his troops
Nabal refuses bread to David's men
The widow at Zarephath feeds Elijah and is rewarded
Jeremiah's rations in prison
the temptation of Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: A diet consisting solely of bread was indicative of deprivation

secondaryrefs.comment: David and his men eat the consecrated bread
Jesus Christ and his disciples in the cornfields on the Sabbath

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as the bread of life
The breaking of bread as a symbol of the death of Jesus Christ
Breakfast is the first meal of the day

children.title: brier
children.comment: Prickly vegetation, painful to the touch, often seen as a symbol of dereliction.

cschildren.title: A brier as a symbol of dereliction
Briers as an instrument of punishment

children.title: cedar
children.comment: A tall, majestic tree, native to Lebanon. In OT times it was highly prized for its wood, which was used extensively in the construction of Solomon's temple.

cschildren.title: The cedar as a tall, majestic tree
Cedar trees indicating a fertile, well-watered land

secondaryrefs.comment: prophecy of a Davidic king being taken into captivity
prophecy of the Messiah coming from David's family

cschildren.title: Cedar as a costly and valued wood
Cedar wood used in ritual purification
Cedar wood imported from the north
Cedar wood used in the construction of buildings

children.title: chaff
children.comment: Husks of wheat or other cereal. It was separated from the grain by threshing, whereupon it usually blew away, as it was lighter than the grain. Sometimes however, it was burned as fuel. The wicked are frequently likened to chaff in Scripture.

cschildren.title: Grain was threshed on outdoor threshing-floors to separate the chaff

children.title: It is blown by the wind

cschildren.title: The wicked are compared to chaff

children.title: They will disappear as chaff is blown away
Their punishment is compared to threshing
Their end will be like chaff which is burned
corn
children.comment: A cereal crop cultivated for food use. An important agricultural crop in biblical times, it is mentioned frequently in Scripture.

children.title: It was an important cereal crop
crops
children.comment: Crops represent God's provision and are regulated by the Mosaic law. Their failure is associated with disobedience.

cschildren.title: Crops related to the law of Moses

seealsos.comment: the Feast of Tabernacles

cschildren.title: The failure of crops as a result of disobedience

children.title: dough
children.comment: A mixture of flour and water to which yeast is added and which is then baked to produce bread. Scripture makes several comparisons with it to teach spiritual lessons.

cschildren.title: Dough and the process of making bread

children.title: Yeast was normally added and the dough left to rise

cschildren.title: Spiritual lessons from comparisons with dough

children.title: The influence of yeast on the dough
drinking
children.comment: Scripture lays down no general prohibition of the consumption of alcohol, but warns against its abuse.

children.title: Wine as a gift of God

seealsos.comment: approval implicit in the advice given

children.title: Withdrawal of wine is evidence of divine judgment
Drinking used extensively as a metaphor
Of Jesus Christ's destiny of suffering
Of the Christian experience of the Holy Spirit
Jesus Christ's symbolic use of wine

seealsos.comment: the believer's participation in Jesus Christ

children.title: drinking, abstention from
children.comment: Scripture indicates that the abuse of drinking, such as drunkenness, is unacceptable. It also indicates the advantages of abstention from drinking in certain situations.

children.title: For some, at certain times, total abstinence is right

secondaryrefs.comment: priests
Nazirites
Jesus Christ
the Christian who does not want to give offence

children.title: Warnings against the abuse of alcohol
Christian leaders are to be sober
Some accusations of drunkenness were unfounded

secondaryrefs.comment: the disciples on the day of Pentecost

children.title: Wine as a gift of God

seealsos.comment: approval implicit in the advice given

children.title: Withdrawal of wine is evidence of divine judgment
Drinking used extensively as a metaphor
Of Jesus Christ's destiny of suffering
Of the Christian experience of the Holy Spirit
Jesus Christ's symbolic use of wine

seealsos.comment: the believer's participation in Jesus Christ

children.title: drinking, abstention from
children.comment: Scripture indicates that the abuse of drinking, such as drunkenness, is unacceptable. It also indicates the advantages of abstention from drinking in certain situations.

children.title: For some, at certain times, total abstinence is right

secondaryrefs.comment: priests
Nazirites
Jesus Christ
the Christian who does not want to give offence

children.title: Warnings against the abuse of alcohol
Christian leaders are to be sober
Some accusations of drunkenness were unfounded

secondaryrefs.comment: the disciples on the day of Pentecost

children.title: eating
children.comment: The consumption of food, necessary for survival. Scripture cites enjoyment of eating as a gift of God but emphasises that it is not the main priority in life, for God will provide abundantly for his children.

cschildren.title: Eating as a sign of life and health
Enjoyment of eating as a gift of God
God blesses his people with sufficient food
Eating should not be one's chief priority

children.title: The Passover and Feast of Unleavened Bread

seealsos.comment: Eve and Adam eat the fruit of the tree
clean and unclean food

children.title: Eating as a guest in another's home

primaryrefs.comment: Coming to faith in Jesus Christ

children.title: fig-tree
children.comment: A tree common in the Near East, with soft, sweet fruit which can be eaten fresh or dried. The fruit was an important part of the diet in biblical times and the tree was symbolic of peace and security.

children.title: Figs prized as a sweet, pleasant fruit
Figs a significant part of the diet in biblical times
Figs given in gifts of food
Other uses of figs and fig leaves

cschildren.title: The fig-tree as a symbol of peace and security
Descriptions of the fig-tree and its fruit
Fig-trees in the teaching of Jesus Christ and the apostles

children.title: firstfruits
children.comment: Offerings of the produce of the land, being the first and best of the crops, given in acknowledgment of God's abundant blessings. The term is also used metaphorically to indicate the first of a much larger group that is to follow, such as those who will be raised from the dead.

cschildren.title: Firstfruits given to priests and Levites
Firstborn of human beings and animals regarded as firstfruits

children.title: Jesus Christ the firstfruits of the resurrection

cschildren.title: Flax is the linum plant from which linen is made

children.title: flowers
children.comment: The blossoming part of plants and trees, from which the seeds or fruit develop. Often admired for their beauty, Scripture uses their fleeting existence as an illustration of the transience of human life.

cschildren.title: Metaphorical depictions of people as flowers
Human existence is likened to the short life cycle of flowers
Forests the habitat of wild animals

children.title: To render land suitable for human habitation
The Palace of the Forest of Lebanon
fruit
children.comment: Edible produce of trees, usually sweet and pleasant-tasting. The climate of the Near East is particularly suitable for a wide range of fruit and several varieties are mentioned in Scripture.

children.title: Representations of pomegranates in the tabernacle and temple

cschildren.title: Fruit as a symbol of spiritual growth
Gall was offered to Jesus Christ at the crucifixion
Gall is a secretion of the liver

children.title: gleaning
children.comment: Picking up grain or fruit left by the harvesters.

cschildren.title: Gleaning used figuratively, to mean something insignificant

children.title: grain
children.comment: The seed of cereals. Together with wine and oil, it was one of the three basic commodities in biblical times. Grain offerings were central to Israelite religion and tithes and firstfruits of grain were also given to God.

cschildren.title: Allusions to grain in the teaching of Jesus Christ

children.title: grape
children.comment: Fruit which grows in clusters on a vine. It was very widely cultivated in the Near East in biblical times and was used mostly for making wine.

cschildren.title: The cultivation of grapes indicative of rich and fertile land
The failure of the grape harvest indicative of misfortune or disaster
Nazirites were forbidden to consume grapes or grape products

children.title: grass
children.comment: Green vegetation, which grows rapidly after rainfall, and serves as good food for many animals. The withering of grass in hot weather is often used in Scripture as a symbol of the frailty and brevity of human life.

cschildren.title: Rain is essential for the growth of grass
Grass withers, dies and burns easily
The life cycle of grass is short
The brevity of human life is compared to that of grass

seealsos.comment: Samson doing a woman's work

cschildren.title: Grinding as an act of destruction

children.title: harvest
children.comment: The gathering of mature crops from the land. The successful culmination of the agricultural year was evidence of God's goodness and consequently marked with festivity. Harvest is also used widely in a metaphorical sense.

cschildren.title: The harvest is evidence of God's goodness
Harvest marked times of the year
Failed harvests are a sign of God's judgment

seealsos.comment: the parable of the growing seed
the parable of the tenants

children.title: herbs and spices
children.comment: Plants whose leaves or seeds are used as food or flavourings and sometimes for medicine. The rich variety of such plants in the Near East results in numerous references in Scripture.

children.title: Given as gifts or as tribute
horticulture
children.comment: The art of garden cultivation, first practised in the Garden of Eden.

cschildren.title: Horticulture in the Garden of Eden

children.title: The man and woman tended the garden
The fall brought about a change in human priorities from horticulture to agriculture

cschildren.title: Egyptian agriculture is likened to horticulture
Horticulture is totally dependent on good irrigation

children.title: hyssop
children.comment: A plant closely associated with cleansing in the OT, being used extensively in rituals for purification.

children.title: At the slaughter of the red heifer

cschildren.title: Ornamental representations of lilies adorned Solomon's temple
Lilies mentioned in some titles of tunes in the Psalms

children.title: manna
children.comment: The source of food provided miraculously for the children of Israel during their desert wanderings. The NT sees this heavenly food as a symbol of Jesus Christ as the bread of life.

children.title: A type of the word of God
meals
children.comment: Food eaten at set times, on special occasions or following significant events. Sacrificial meals formed part of Israelite worship in the OT, as does the Lord's Supper for worship by believers in the NT.

children.title: meat
children.comment: The flesh of animals, consumed as food. In biblical times it was a luxury, eaten on special occasions, usually in the context of sacrificial worship.

cschildren.title: Restrictions on eating certain types of meat
Allegorical and metaphorical references to meat

children.title: milk
children.comment: A common source of food and nourishment, associated with rich and productive land. The term is also used figuratively as a form of spiritual food suitable for those who have yet to reach maturity in the Christian faith.

cschildren.title: Milk as a source of nourishment

seealsos.comment: illustrating the support of the ministry

cschildren.title: Milk as an indication of prosperity and well-being

primaryrefs.comment: A frequent description of the promised land

cschildren.title: Elementary Christian teaching likened to milk

children.title: millstones
children.comment: Pairs of upper and lower millstones were used for grinding grain in the ancient East. Millstones were common features of the daily life of ordinary people.

cschildren.title: Millstones as a means of earning a living
Millstones as symbols of destructive force

children.title: mustard seed
children.comment: A very small seed which grew rapidly into a substantial plant. It was used in parables by Jesus Christ to encourage the faith of the individual and to illustrate the growth of the kingdom of God.

cschildren.title: The mustard seed and the faith of the individual
The mustard seed and the kingdom of God

children.title: myrrh
children.comment: A resinous substance derived from certain trees and bushes native to the Near East. It was a valuable commodity and had a variety of uses.

cschildren.title: Myrrh was presented as a gift

children.title: oil
children.comment: Normally olive oil, which was in plentiful supply in Israel and in general household use. Its ritual uses included the anointing of priests and kings and ceremonial cleansing; in the NT oil was used to anoint the sick. As a sign of God's provision for his people, oil was associated with prosperity and gladness, and was a mark of spiritual blessing.

secondaryrefs.comment: Olives were pressed either with a pestle and mortar or in a stone press
``Gethsemane'' means ``oil press'', named after the stone presses associated with the Mount of Olives.

cschildren.title: Oil for use in the sanctuary

children.title: Instructions for making and using the anointing oil
Holy objects were consecrated by anointing with oil
children.precomment: Jacob twice anoints a pillar at Bethel:

children.title: Priests were ordained by anointing with oil

secondaryrefs.comment: Saul
Solomon
Jehu
with the thank offering
at the completion of the Nazirite's vow

children.title: Oil was excluded from certain offerings

cschildren.title: Oil used to anoint the sick

children.title: Oil as a sign of God's blessing
Oil withdrawn as a sign of judgment
Renewed provision of oil following restoration
The firstfruits of the oil harvest
Oil as a commodity for trade
Oil as a sign of prosperity

primaryrefs.comment: The joy with which God anoints his servants is likened to the oil which anoints the bridegroom in preparation for his wedding.

seealsos.comment: Oil draws attention away from the fact that a person is fasting

children.title: Oil as a sign of honour

primaryrefs.comment: Oil was used to anoint the heads of honoured guests at a meal.

children.title: ointment
children.comment: A liquid blend of aromatic substances, usually spices, used as a cosmetic and also as a medicinal balm. Lotions were applied to the body to refresh, to improve appearance and to give a pleasing fragrance. Balm, especially from Gilead, was used to soothe pain and to heal wounds.

primaryrefs.comment: One way of making ointment was to crush solid ingredients and boil them together in olive oil.

children.title: Preparation of the holy anointing oil

seealsos.comment: The holy anointing oil was to be prepared only by those authorised to do so.

children.title: To anoint the heads of guests

seealsos.comment: This may reflect the custom of anointing a guest with perfumed ointment which melted and ran down the face and clothes to produce a pleasing fragrance

primaryrefs.comment: (Spike)nard was an expensive import from India.

seealsos.comment: The use of expensive ointments was a mark of luxury

children.title: Oil used to soothe and heal

primaryrefs.comment: Gilead was famous for its healing balsam.

children.title: olive
children.comment: An evergreen tree native to the Near East. Also the fruit of this tree, for which it is cultivated. The fruit can be eaten or pressed to produce oil for food or other uses.

children.title: Olive oil used in the tabernacle
Payment, tribute and trade in olive oil
Olive trees cultivated for their fruit

seealsos.comment: the grafting of olive trees

children.title: papyrus
children.comment: A large plant growing in marshland, sometimes to a height of six metres.

cschildren.title: Papyrus was used for making boats
Papyrus indicates an ample water supply

secondaryrefs.comment: Papyrus growing in what was once desert depicts the blessing coming on God's redeemed people.

cschildren.title: Examples of the use of perfume

children.title: Commissioned to make oil and incense for the sanctuary

seealsos.comment: The manufacture of the sacred anointing oil by unauthorised persons was forbidden

secondaryrefs.comment: perfumers in the service of the king
Hananiah

children.title: ploughing
children.comment: Cutting up the furrows in soil and turning it up before work can be done on the land.

cschildren.title: Ploughing as a way of life

children.title: poison
children.comment: A substance obtained from plants or animals that can cause illness, pain, disability or death. It is often used symbolically to refer to distress or bitterness.

children.title: Poison from plants, water or food
To refer to distress
children.precomment: In these incidences God himself is portrayed as the one who brings such bitter experiences:

children.title: To refer to evil and its effects

cschildren.title: A plant that grows in water
Reeds are weak and fragile plants

children.title: roots
children.comment: The source and foundation of a tree or plant, anchoring it to the soil, usually found beneath the surface of the ground. Scripture contains literal, metaphorical and figurative references to roots.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as the ``Root of David''

children.title: Individuals and nations depicted as trees or plants with roots

seealsos.comment: the LORD's sign to Hezekiah
the parable of the sower

children.title: Sources and foundations described as roots

cschildren.title: Roots as a symbol of stability and growth

children.title: seed
children.comment: The means of propagating life from one generation to another. Figuratively, the term illustrates principles of spiritual life and growth, especially in later parts of the OT and throughout the NT.

children.title: The presence of seed was a blessing
The absence of seed was a curse

cschildren.title: Regulations in the law concerning seed
Seed used figuratively to illustrate kingdom life

children.title: To illustrate those ready to enter the kingdom of God
To illustrate birth into eternal life
To illustrate the growth of the kingdom of God
To illustrate the growth of the church
To illustrate God's word and people's response to it

seealsos.comment: the parable of the sower

children.title: To illustrate the principle that death comes before life

cschildren.title: God calls his people to sow seeds of righteousness

children.title: sickle
children.comment: A cutting tool with a short handle used in harvesting grain. Early blades were made of wood lined with flint teeth; these were later replaced with curved iron blades. The cutting down of grain at harvest with a sickle is used as a symbol of God's judgment.

seealsos.comment: Sickles were not to be used in another person's field

cschildren.title: Cutting down grain as a symbol of judgment

children.title: sowing and reaping
children.comment: OT references are mainly agricultural with regulatory laws covering crop production and festivals of thanksgiving. God's blessing was reflected in the harvest. The NT refers more to the spiritual sowing and reaping that takes place in the kingdom of God.

cschildren.title: Regulations concerning the sowing and reaping of crops

children.title: Laws of purity related to planting
Reapers are to leave gleanings for the poor
The Sabbath-rest for the land and its cultivators

cschildren.title: Reaping a good harvest is a blessing from God

children.title: It is a consequence of obedience
It is a promise to the remnant of God's people

cschildren.title: God's judgment on Israel is reflected in reaping a poor harvest

children.title: The harvesting of one's crops by others

cschildren.title: Proverbs and poems of sowing and harvest
Moral and spiritual sowing and reaping

children.title: Sowing and reaping in the kingdom of God
Reaping a material harvest from spiritual sowing

cschildren.title: People and nations are reaped for judgment
Metaphorical use of sowing and reaping
The staff was a basic item of personal property

children.title: It was carried at most times

cschildren.title: The staff was sometimes a symbol of authority
God's miraculous power was manifest through Moses' and Aaron's staffs

secondaryrefs.comment: the plague of blood
the plague of frogs
the plague of gnats
the plague of hail
the plague of locusts
the parting of the Red Sea

cschildren.title: Literal uses of a stick of wood

children.title: Elisha and the axe-head that floats

cschildren.title: The lightness and fragility of straw
Sycamore-fig trees were plentiful in Judea
Thorns and thistles as the result of the curse of the fall
Thorns and thistles as worthless weeds
Thorns unpleasant and to be avoided
Thorns used as instruments of punishment
Thorns indicative of desolation and dereliction

children.title: threshing
children.comment: The process of beating out or separating grain from harvested stalks.

seealsos.comment: Paul is adapting a humane OT law to the support of Christian workers.

primaryrefs.comment: A threshing-sledge was a board studded underneath with sharp stones which was dragged by oxen over the wheat ears in order to separate the kernels.

children.title: threshing-floor
children.comment: The place where winnowing and threshing took place at harvest time.

cschildren.title: The threshing-floor as a symbol of harvest
The threshing-floor as a symbol of judgment
A threshing-floor was the site of the Jerusalem temple

children.title: tree of life
children.comment: One of two trees situated in the centre of the Garden of Eden. It is also mentioned in Revelation, where it symbolises life and salvation.

cschildren.title: The tree of life in the Garden of Eden
The tree of life in Revelation
The tree of life as a metaphor

children.title: trees
children.comment: Large, woody plants with trunk, branches, leaves and roots, noted for their long lives. Scripture refers to many different varieties of tree.

children.title: As a symbol of permanence or long life
The trees of life and knowledge
As an example of distorted vision
unleavened bread
children.comment: Bread baked without yeast, often made because of insufficient time to prepare bread in the conventional manner. It was also eaten at the Passover Feast and was presented with sacrifices and offerings.

cschildren.title: Unleavened bread eaten to commemorate the Passover
Unleavened bread presented to God as an offering

children.title: vine
children.comment: A plant on which grapes grow, cultivated primarily for making wine. Jesus Christ described himself as the true vine, the source of life and growth for all believers.

cschildren.title: The vine as an image of peace and security
Laws relating to the cultivation of vines
The destruction of vines as punishment
Israel is described as a vine
Jesus Christ is the true vine
Vinegar as an acid, reacting vigorously with alkaline soda
Vinegar as a substitute for wine

children.title: It was offered to Jesus Christ at the crucifixion
vineyard
children.comment: A cultivated field or garden, sometimes surrounded by a wall, in which vines and other trees were grown. Israel is sometimes compared to a vineyard. Some of Jesus Christ's parables concern vineyards.

cschildren.title: Vineyards were sometimes surrounded by walls
Vineyards were associated with a settled, peaceful life
Vineyards were a sign of wealth
The produce of vineyards not enjoyed by owner

seealsos.comment: the parable of the workers in the vineyard
the parable of the tenants

children.title: weeds
children.comment: Uncultivated plants or shrubs, growing wild, often among cultivated crops or plants. Jesus Christ used the image of weeds in some of his parables to illustrate sin and worldliness.

cschildren.title: The presence of weeds indicates desolation and neglect
Weeds were a serious problem for the farmer
Some varieties of weed were painful to the touch
Weeds in Jesus Christ's parables
cschildren.precomment: The parable of the sower and its explanation:

children.title: wheat
children.comment: A cereal widely cultivated for use as food. One of the main agricultural crops in biblical times, it is referred to throughout the Scriptures and features several times in Jesus Christ's teaching.

children.title: The parable of the wheat and the weeds
wine
children.comment: Drink made from fermented grape juice, often drunk instead of water in biblical times. Scripture recognises the richness of wine and its value in bringing joy to people; however, it condemns the excessive drinking of wine, and recommends total abstinence in some situations.

cschildren.title: Wine as a sign of blessing
Lack of wine as a sign of God's displeasure
Wine as an alternative to water
The pleasant taste and effects of wine

seealsos.comment: Noah
Lot and his daughters

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ's miracle of water turned into wine

primaryrefs.comment: God's wrath is often pictured as a cup of wine to be drunk.

seealsos.comment: quenching spiritual thirst
illustrating judgment and the moral decadence of Babylon the Great

cschildren.title: Wine as a symbol of the suffering and death of Jesus Christ

children.title: winepress
children.comment: The vat in which grapes were trodden to produce juice for making wine. Scripture sometimes uses the image of treading grapes at the winepress to depict scenes of divine wrath and punishment.

cschildren.title: The association of winepresses with harvest

children.title: wineskin
children.comment: A container or sack, made from animal skin to hold wine. Jesus Christ used the image of old and new wineskins to explain the differences between himself and John the Baptist.

cschildren.title: Wineskins used to store or carry wine

primaryrefs.comment: New wine was stored in new wineskins, which expanded with the wine as it fermented.

cschildren.title: The parable of old and new wineskins

children.title: winnowing
children.comment: The exposing of grain to the air by either tossing or fanning so that the loose outer part is blown away. It is also used figuratively to refer to God's judgment.

cschildren.title: Winnowing took place at the threshing-floor

children.title: wood
children.comment: Trunks and branches of trees used as raw material for various objects and as fuel for burning. Acacia wood was used extensively in the tabernacle and olive wood in the temple.

children.title: yeast
children.comment: A raising agent commonly used in bread. Bread that was required quickly was baked without yeast, as at the first Passover, commemorated annually in the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Although some non-meat offerings contained yeast, it could not be burned on the altar.

cschildren.title: Unleavened bread was made without yeast
The consumption of yeast was prohibited during the Feast of Unleavened Bread
Sacrifices burned on the altar were not to contain yeast
Yeast as an image of the kingdom of God
Metaphorical references to yeast as something evil
